title: Donald Trump keeps his promise on Syria, driving the Deep State crazy | Mulshine
text:
What took him so long?

That’s the question we should be asking about President Trump’s decision to remove troops from Syria.

If you paid attention to Donald Trump’s comments on foreign affairs during the 2016 campaign, you heard a lot of pronouncements like the following:

“The United States has spent EIGHT TRILLION DOLLARS fighting and policing in the Middle East. Thousands of our Great Soldiers have died or been badly wounded. Millions of people have died on the other side. GOING INTO THE MIDDLE EAST IS THE WORST DECISION EVER MADE.....”

That’s actually a Trump tweet from Wednesday. But the tone doesn’t vary from what he was saying in 2016. Apparently his Caps Lock key has been stuck for all that time as well.

That The Donald is finally following through on his promises should be no great surprise to the politicians and the pundits.

Nonetheless, Trump is getting it from both sides. His decision to pull U.S. troops out of the border zone in the Kurdish-occupied part of Syria has been blasted by Democratic House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Republican Senate President Mitch McConnell.

But one New Jersey politician who was Trump’s first major supporter in the 2016 race said he thinks Trump’s decision is a step in the right direction.

“I think it’s fantastic that he’s finally starting to get us out of the Mideast,” said state Sen. Mike Doherty.

The Warren County Republican, who is a West Point grad and former Army officer, said The Donald’s foreign policy was the main reason he supported him over Kentucky Senator Rand Paul in the 2016 GOP primaries.

“I supported Donald Trump over Rand Paul because Donald Trump was the closest candidate to Ron Paul when it came to foreign policy and stopping military adventures all over the world,” he said.

Ron Paul is the former Texas congressman who shocked the Republican leadership in the 2008 race by calling the Iraq War a major mistake. In the 2016 primary debates, Trump went after the man whose brother was responsible for that blunder.

“The way he took down Jeb Bush in the South Carolina debate was the greatest ever,” said Doherty.

After that debate, most of the GOP establishment pols and pundits predicted Trump’s anti-war tirades would cost him the nomination.

The voting public had other ideas. But the inside-the-Beltway establishment still backs the foreign policy that calls for the U.S. to sort out the turf wars of the Mideast.

“The people who oppose Trump are the same people who really want to attack Iran,” said Doherty. “They’re really upset because that’s their long-term plan and this is a step in the wrong direction.”

That’s not mere speculation. The man Trump recently dismissed as his National Security Advisor, John Bolton, spent his time in office trying to get the president who campaigned against “regime change” to push for regime change in Iran.

Trump doesn’t mind sending harsh rhetoric Tehran’s way. But with this move, he shows once again he’s serious about getting us out of the region.

I discussed this with another former Army officer, one who watches over Washington from his home in Virginia just outside of the Beltway.

Pat Lang said that we have been at war so long that it seems like a natural state of affairs to the career officers. (Check his blog for the most realistic military analysis of the Mideast you will ever see.)

“The generals we have now have never known peace during their careers,” he said. “I’m sure they cannot imagine being in the Army if there’s not a war going on.”

After serving as a Green Beret in Vietnam, Lang spent most of his career in the peacetime Army. He learned Arabic and spent a couple decades doing intelligence work in places like Iraq and Yemen.

Many pols and pundits are upset that Trump is not ordering military action to protect the Kurds from the Turkish incursion into the part of northeastern Syria that they control. Lang has a harshly realistic view:

“The United States has a long, long record of abandoning allies,” Lang said. “We’ve done it in a lot of places, the worst of which was Vietnam.”

In this case, he said, the Turks are not likely to go very far beyond a buffer zone they have said they want to set up along their border with Syria.

As for sorting out the mess we’ve made in Syria, Trump was wise not to take on that task. He issued another tweet last week that explained his reasoning.

“Should have never been there in the first place!”

No, we shouldn’t have.

The establishment may not be upset about the 18 years of war we’ve had since 9/11.

But I suspect the voters have a different view.
